core

core.Gaussian_probabilities module

core.Gaussian_probabilities.compute_probability_intervals(args, model, partition, frs, max_slice)[source]

Compute probability intervals for all states and actions of the IMDP.

Parameters:

  • args – Argument object.

  • model – Model object.

  • partition – Partition object.

  • frs – Forward reachable sets.

  • max_slice – Array where each element is the maximum number of partition elements to consider in each dimension.

Returns:

  • prob: Probability intervals per state-action pair

  • prob_id: Successor states associated with these probability intervals per state-action pair

  • prob_absorbing: Probability interval of reaching the absorbing state per state-action pair

core.Gaussian_probabilities.dynslice(V, idx_low, size)[source]

Given a vector of indices, keep only those starting at position idx_low and of length size.

Parameters:

  • V – Vector of indices.

  • idx_low – Index to start slice at.

  • size – Number of elements to keep in slice.

Returns:

Slice of V.

core.Gaussian_probabilities.integ_Gauss(x_lb, x_ub, x, cov)[source]

Integrate a univariate Gaussian distribution over a given interval.

Parameters:

  • x_lb – Lower bound of the interval.

  • x_ub – Upper bound of the interval.

  • x – Mean of the Gaussian distribution.

  • cov – Covariance of the Gaussian distribution.

Returns:

core.Gaussian_probabilities.interval_distribution_per_dim(n, max_slice, wrap, wrap_array, decimals, number_per_dim, per_dim_lb, per_dim_ub, i_lb, mean_lb, mean_ub, cov, state_space_lb, state_space_ub, region_idx_array, unsafe_states)[source]

For a given state-action pair, compute the probability intervals over all successor states.

core.Gaussian_probabilities.minmax_Gauss(x_lb, x_ub, mean_lb, mean_ub, cov, wrap_array)[source]

Compute the min/max integral of a multivariate Gaussian distribution over a given interval, where the mean of the Gaussian lies in [mean_lb, mean_ub].

Parameters:

  • x_lb – Lower bound of the interval.

  • x_ub – Upper bound of the interval.

  • mean_lb – Lower bound of the mean of the Gaussian distribution.

  • mean_ub – Upper bound of the mean of the Gaussian distribution.

  • cov – Covariance of the Gaussian distribution.

  • wrap_array – Wrap at the indices where this array is True.

Returns:

Min/max probabilities.

core.Gaussian_probabilities.minmax_Gauss_per_dim(n, wrap, x_lb_per_dim, x_ub_per_dim, mean_lb, mean_ub, cov, state_space_size)[source]

Compute the min/max integral of a multivariate Gaussian distribution over a given interval, where the mean of the Gaussian lies in [mean_lb, mean_ub]. Exploit rectangular partition to compute much fewer Gaussian integrals

Parameters:

  • n – Dimension of the state space.

  • wrap – Wrap at the indices where this array is True.

  • x_lb_per_dim – Lower bound of the interval per dimension.

  • x_ub_per_dim – Upper bound of the interval per dimension.

  • mean_lb – Lower bound of the mean of the Gaussian distribution.

  • mean_ub – Upper bound of the mean of the Gaussian distribution.

  • cov – Covariance of the Gaussian distribution.

  • state_space_size – Size of the state space per dimension (i.e., size of the “state space box”)

Returns:

  • Min/max probabilities.

  • Lower bound probabilities.

  • Upper bound probabilities.

core.Gaussian_probabilities.vmap_integ_Gauss(x_lb, x_ub, x, cov)

Vectorized version of integ_Gauss. Takes similar arguments as integ_Gauss but with additional array axes over which integ_Gauss is mapped.

Original documentation:

core.actions_forward module

class core.actions_forward.RectangularForward(partition, model)[source]

Bases: object

core.actions_forward.forward_reach(step_set, state_min, state_max, input, cov_diag, number_per_dim, cell_width, boundary_lb, boundary_ub)[source]

Computes the forward reachable set given a set of input parameters.

Parameters:

  • step_set – Function that computes the minimum and maximum reachable states given the state bounds and input.

  • state_min – Lower bound of the box (of states ) to propagate.

  • state_max – Upper bound of the box (of states ) to propagate.

  • input – Control input for the dynamical system.

  • cov_diag – Diagonal entries of the covariance matrix

  • number_per_dim – The number of cells per dimension in the state space grid.

  • cell_width – The width of cells along each dimension.

  • boundary_lb – The lower bound of the grid of the state space.

  • boundary_ub – The upper bound of the grid of the state space.

Returns:

A tuple containing: - frs_min: The minimum bound of the forward reachable set. - frs_max: The maximum bound of the forward reachable set. - frs_span: The number of grid cells encompassed by the forward reachable set. - idx_low: The lower index bounds in the grid corresponding to the forward reachable set. - idx_upp: The upper index bounds in the grid corresponding to the forward reachable set.

core.model module

core.model.make_fully_actuated(model, manualDimension='auto')[source]

Given a parsed model, render it fully actuated. Only available for linear models.

Parameters:

  • model – Parsed model object.

  • manualDimension – Integer or ‘auto’. If ‘auto’, then the dimension is determined automatically. If an integer, than that number of of time steps is lumped together used.

Returns:

Model object.

core.partition module

class core.partition.RectangularPartition(model)[source]

Bases: object

Represents a rectangular partitioning of a state space into hyperrectangular regions.

This class is used to define and manage a partition of a state space, where the space is divided into hyperrectangular regions (or cells). Each cell is defined by its center, bounds, and vertices, and the entirety of these regions form a structured grid within the state space.

x2state(x)[source]

Return the state ID for a given point x in the continuous state space.

Parameters:

x – Point in the continuous state space.

Returns:

State ID.

core.polytope module

core.polytope.all_points_in_polytope(A, b, points)[source]

Check if polytope defined by Ax <= b contains given list of points

core.polytope.any_points_in_polytope(A, b, points)[source]

Check if polytope defined by Ax <= b contains given list of points

core.polytope.hyperrectangles_isdisjoint(lb1, ub1, lb2, ub2)[source]

Check if two hyperrectangles are disjoint.

Algorithm: H1 \cap H2 are not disjoint iff |c_2 - c_1| \leq r_1 + r_2, where \leq is taken component-wise.

core.polytope.hyperrectangles_isdisjoint_multi(lb1, ub1, lbs2, ubs2)[source]

Check if one hyperrectangle (lb1, ub1) is disjoint from multiple other hyperrectangles given by (lbs2, ubs2)

Algorithm: H1 \cap H2 are not disjoint iff |c_2 - c_1| \leq r_1 + r_2, where \leq is taken component-wise.

core.polytope.num_points_in_polytope(A, b, points)[source]

Check if polytope defined by Ax <= b contains given list of points

core.polytope.points_in_polytope(A, b, points)[source]

Check if polytope defined by Ax <= b contains given list of points

core.polytope.vmap_hyperrectangles_isdisjoint(lb1, ub1, lb2, ub2)

Vectorized version of hyperrectangles_isdisjoint. Takes similar arguments as hyperrectangles_isdisjoint but with additional array axes over which hyperrectangles_isdisjoint is mapped.

Original documentation:

Check if two hyperrectangles are disjoint.

Algorithm: H1 \cap H2 are not disjoint iff |c_2 - c_1| \leq r_1 + r_2, where \leq is taken component-wise.

core.utils.create_batches(data_length, batch_size)[source]

Create batches for the given data and batch size. Returns the start and end indices to iterate over.

Parameters:

  • batch_size – Number of points per batch.

Returns:

Each batch is represented by the slice [starts[i]:ends[i]].
